comments.commentBody: A magnificent experiment. Congratulations to the whole crew that made it possible, and to the dedication of years of their lives to a dream.

You make a good point. The reason for the poll numbers is that many voters conflate the deficit with the debt.

And the debt is actually worrisome, because real interest rates will not stay negative forever, unless we have entered an endless depression.
They lost so much money in the financial crisis, their tax-loss carryforwards may last years.  But under normal circumstances, they pay a tax rate of about 42%.
As always, we see a consequence of rescinding Glass-Steagal...
B of A and UBS pay little or no taxes, , but are allowed to suck the corpse of the dying city dry. Something is very wrong.

Yes, it was the Brotherhood that failed to prevent a coup. The Brotherhood failed to establish genuine civil government control of its own military.

Erdogan take note. The same interests will come for you if they can. It is already promoted by the same interests in think tanks and press.

Laszlo, thank you for throwing a ringer into the usually stodgy part that I'm sure most people skim over. Someone should slap the bracelets on you for that Vienna WRIST BAND.

The old one-two punch, you never see it coming...

More puns, less crunch, but a collection of solid entries throughout the grid, the sign of a seasoned professional who will not be satisfied with second choices.

It gave me a pleasure each time I came to a nice word like OGIVE (new to me), PREEMPTED, LEAD FOOT, ERGONOMICS, SEATMATE, etc. Favorite clue: Summer symbol.

NEAR MISS is a strange phrase meaning the opposite:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zuCN6CD8j_s

Here is Mozart's PRAGUE Symphony, No. 38 in D, played by the BATES MOTEL Symphony. Kidding, of course, it's the Vienna WRIST BAND:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fi1L55GR0BE

Have a lovely Friday.

"The age old tactic by Republicans is to paint Democrats as profligate wasteful spenders that will ruin our future if left to their own devices."

They're way past that and into lying about the Democrats giving away their hard earned "free money" to garner votes and other lies, on top of lying about the debt and deficit not only to their own, but also moderate Democrats. I spent a couple of hours trying to convince a long-time friend of mine that Fix The Debt is a wolf in sheep's clothing. No article from our good professor, Robert Reich, Joe Stiglitz or anyone else would change his mind.

The propaganda machine is in full motion and it works on many levels.

You are probably correct on all three points, but your first point is especially interesting. People are not stupid just because they are unfamiliar with specialized jargon and, while Washington insiders probably think that terms like deficit and debt are as common as terms like income and expenses, for most people they are not nearly so familiar. How many people ever use the term "deficit" when describing their own financial situation? So this begs the question of why pollsters do not clearly define their terms when they ask their questions. It would seem that they want to create the impression that the public is generally ignorant. It is my experience that a pollster will not clarify the questions even when asked to because this might skew the results. Such a system may pass the rigorous tests of statistical significance, but hardly is effective if the goal is to learn what people actually know and think. My guess is that were the poll to have two questions, "What is meant by deficit?" and "Has the deficit been increasing?" you would some interesting correlations.
Alien sabotage.  They don't want us to find what's out there  :)

Yes, but you can't judge based on a single sentence in an article. Who knows, the friction could have posed some other problem that's not obvious. Shaking the camera and resulting in useless pictures, as a made-up example.

@Elliot...

No, no, no, a thousand times no! Friction kills reaction wheels -- even if they are still spinning at some rate albeit it hindered. Friction can prevent a wheel from producing the required revolutions needed for stabilization. If the computer determines wheel x needs y RPMs but wheel x can only spin n RPMs, it CANNOT be used.

Did you not read the part of the article where it said the engineers exhausted all avenues?!?!

The only strange choice here is someone making a comment about spacecraft command and control who clearly doesn't have that experience.

Kepler doesn't orbit earth. It follows earth in its orbit, and it is slightly slower, so it is getting further away from us.

Because of this, it's not like Hubble. Even if we had the space shuttle, there is no craft that could reach it. You'd need an Apollo-like spacecraft that can leave LEO, and you'd have to figure out the gravitational mechanics, if it is even possible to reach it and return to earth.

In short, it's much cheaper to build and launch a replacement.

http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/kepler/multimedia/images/kepler-orbit-...
Because it's in orbit around the Sun, which means that it is NOT in orbit around the Earth. It's not a few thousand miles above us; it's something like 90 million miles away.

Kepler is in orbit around the Sun, not the Earth.  We have never sent people into solar orbit, and we don't have the technology to send an automated repair mission.  It will be much cheaper to send up a replacement.
Seems like they should go up and fix it.  Why not?

Flying the Shuttle costs more than whatever the project is worth. Stupendous failure.

Unmanned flight has always been the way to go if you care about costs.
Why can't we have both?  Because the billionaires want their taxes reduced.

"Scientists expect the spacecraft to drift slowly until it is about 46.5 million miles (75 million kilometers) behind the Earth in four years." from:http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/research/2007/kepler-story.html

Of course if we STILL had an operational Space Shuttle Program, so blithely sacrificed by the administration, we could have an opportunity to try a repair.  But of course we can't have that, the money gets redirected to  administration goals to bolster electability by providing goodies.
You mean 4,800 years times 1,000,000, of course . . .

"We started 4800 years ago."

I assume this is sarcasm, but some people won't take it that way.

I understand that you are being sarcastic, but a good comeback to anyone who actually claims that the earth is 4800 years old is to inform them that there is a bristlecone pine in Great Basin National Park that is approximately 5,000 years old.

Ah, we don't need to spend money on saving this data. Just cut and run. Why do we need to know about the potential for other "earths" since we are the only one and we started 4800 years ago.

OK, cut out all of ACA and we'll give you the money to pay unemployment to all these people who have doing trivial work.

I may be a bit harsh, but I fear that this is only a bit harsh.
Because the heavens know we aren't spending enough money on our military adventures.
Good news! Let's quit wasting precious resources to chase after fantasy dream worlds and put our full attention on the greatest planet in the universe, the one and only EARTH!
If they'd turn it towards Earth and help me find my kid's lost soccer ball, I'd be really grateful!  It is somewhere along the upper west side in Central Park.
You need 3 gyroscopes to know your position along the 3 axes (x, y, z). If not, you don't know which star you're looking at, which makes any observation useless.

They must be able to keep it pointed if not at specific stars, then at least a specific part of space.  I'm thinking a much more focused version of the Sloan sky survey.  Have it monitor the stars around the black hole at the center of the Milky Way.  Or a specific galaxy or region.  Isn't there something out there that we'd benefit from watching for a decade straight?

You need three wheels for precision control in three spatial axes.

Reaction wheels go out often enough that I wonder why they don't send them up with, say, six for complete three-wheel redundancy or even. Kepler launched with four, and now is down to two.

Yes, that means more mass and cost, but it's dumb that two bad wheels have just ended the work of an important, pioneering, $600 million mission. A complete backup reaction wheel set seems small insurance.

Spinning computer hard drives fail sooner or later; wise computer owners prepare for that eventuality and back up their data. Spacecraft designers might take note.
Ok. It proved the hypothesis. Why do we need statistical accuracy? Now we have the opportunity too do something which normally would not have received funding. But what?
It would be like trying to take an eye exam at the doctors across a football field in the dark while wildly swinging a police flashlight

I would suggest the folks at NASA have and will learn from its projects, as any good engineer would.

The incremental-and I mean that as a positive statement-improvement the next effort will contain will and should better allow survey and study of the great space.

I wonder if the current fabulous system could be used for more esoteric study: Could the monitor be fixed in the vast darkness of space to further evaluate dark matter?

Or train it back on earth? look for changes in our planet? The sea for instance?

It might be better to just build *another* more resilient and space hardened vehicle to replace this one and just make sure that it's 5ox structural upgrade.  This way you can have better optics, faster data transfer and storage, and yes a near invincible stabilization system.  This can be done!  So point it into the sun when it's time arrives and move ahead with the lessons from the past well learned.  No shortcuts and no cost-cutting, just ultra-solid engineering and construction.

This article would have been more encouraging had it included a sentence about the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) that is scheduled to launch in 2017 and also search for exoplanets, if I understand correctly. My first thought while reading was, oh no, will it be several decades before we can perform this kind of search again? Apparently and thankfully this is not the case. If I'm wrong on this point, I'd love for someone to correct me. My despair at the seeming end of planet hunting led to a brief search just now that turned up TESS.

I hardly believe that the search for Earth-like worlds is a distraction from preserving Earth. It's not a zero-sum game. The people who are advocating for more space science missions are usually the same well educated realists who understand the importance of science literacy, and the prevention of global warming, among other things.

I also find it hard to believe that people see missions like Kepler and think, "Oh, since we launched a mission to search for Earth-like planets, our Earth is disposable! If this one gets trashed I'll just move to another!"

In the Kepler FAQ NASA states that no manned mission to other planets is remotely feasible:
http://kepler.nasa.gov/mission/faq/#a10

And here's a NASA press release quoting a climatologist that explicitly says the reason we have global warming is from human generated CO2 emissions:
http://www.nasa.gov/topics/earth/features/2012-temps.html

If we really need NASA to explicitly say, "Please guys, this is our only shot for a planet! Don't ruin it!" --then it's already hopeless.

Good thing whoever visited and/or seeded this planet decided differently.  Perhaps it is the filling or fouling of a home planet that gets thinking creatures to go out into space.  There was a time when primitive people walked to a new world when their area climate and/or  food supply changed.  NASA is one agency that gives hope for a better life to many of us.
You hit that nail on the head.  All the talk of putting a man on Mars is equally silly if anyone believes it will provide a refuge from problems on earth.

"Finding another Earth" is a distraction from preserving the one we have under our feet. Are you aware of how many people actually believe -- really, I'm not kidding -- that the human race is going somewhere else?

Where is the NASA publication that explains the potentially useful science that might lie behind these types of explorations, but then says -- in no uncertain terms -- "But seriously, folks, don't think for a space-minute that tantalizing hints of plausible Earthlike worlds have anything remotely to do with actually changing your address. It ain't gonna happen. What you're walking on is your best and only bet. Seriously."

I'd LOVE to hear that from NASA. NASA has done so much for us. That's the one thing they haven't done.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) journal, Science, published a brief biography of Mr. Borucki. I say "Mr." because this incredibly persistent, inquisitive, and innovative man does not have a graduate degree! Scientists have made the argument that he should have an honorary PhD because he basically built Kepler, and magnitude-based planet detection from the ground up. I agree; Kepler would make for a bulletproof graduate project.

Funding was a battle. The Science article describes how he did his proof of concept on a miniscule budget, at one point using a bucket with holes in the bottom to simulate a starry sky. The article, published this spring, is worth seeking out (Science requires a subscription, but you should be able to find it at your local library) both for an explanation of the Kepler project and its genesis, and the story of William Borucki.

I agree.  Kelper is a great mission and there are so many more: Curiosity on Mars, Cassini at Saturn, the Spitzer infrared space telescope, solar observing spacecraft (did you see the tornadoes on the sun) and the cosmic background observer (Planck) for cosmology studies.  Then on the ground in Chile there is the ALMA array of radio telescopes which has unprecedented resolution.  Amazing stuff is coming out of all these.

"To NASA and all space scientists: Thanks for trying to carry us forward!"

+1

Whatever...all I know is that I am always happy to see an article about NASA and space exploration. Even when it's bad news, it reminds me that we humans have so much more to do than squabble over stupid politics and religion and all that daily nonsense. To NASA and all space scientists: Thanks for trying to carry us forward!
